profile: Spanish nobleman, third Superior General of the Jesuits, known for humility and reform.
Pope known for convening Vatican II; promoted peace and modern renewal in the Church.
Capuchin lay brother noted for humility, piety, and miracles of healing.
Anglo-Saxon king renowned for justice, piety, and charitable works.
Pope and martyr, former slave, known for mercy and promoting reconciliation.
Carmelite reformer, mystic, author; led renewal of spiritual life in Europe.
French mystic who promoted devotion to the Sacred Heart of Jesus.
Early Church Father, bishop, martyr, author of influential letters on Church unity.
Physician and companion of Paul, author of a Gospel and the Acts of the Apostles.

saintName: Saints John de Brébeuf, Isaac Jogues, and Companions
profile: French missionaries martyred while evangelizing native peoples in America.
Passionist founder known for preaching and deep devotion to Christ's Passion.
Hermit from Palestine, founder of monasticism in the region.
Pope, philosopher, author, played a key role in fall of communism, traveler.
Franciscan missionary and crusader; known for preaching across Europe.
Missionary bishop, founder, writer, worked in Cuba and Spain.
Brazilian Franciscan noted for charity and founding religious institutions.
Early Scottish bishop and missionary.
First bishop of Ethiopia, brought Christianity to the region.
Two of the Twelve Apostles, remembered for missionary journeys and martyrdom.
Early bishop of Jerusalem, reputed for miracles and piety.
Jesuit lay brother known for humility and spiritual advice.
Franciscan missionary and mystic, remembered for sanctity and miracles.

The Solemnity of All Saints honors all the saints known and unknown who have attained heaven. It celebrates the diverse communion of saints as models of holiness and intercessors for the faithful on earth. This feast encourages the Church to strive for holiness and faithfulness to Christ.

All Souls Day is dedicated to prayers for the souls of the faithful departed. The Church encourages the faithful to assist the souls in purgatory through prayers, Masses, and acts of charity, fostering hope in the resurrection and eternal life promised by Christ.

Martin de Porres, born in Lima, Peru, in 1579, was of mixed race and dedicated himself to a life of charity as a Dominican lay brother. Known for his care of the sick and poor, he performed miracles and is the patron of racial harmony and social justice. Canonized in 1962, he inspires compassion and humility.

Charles Borromeo (1538-1584), Archbishop of Milan, was a leading figure in the Counter-Reformation. He implemented the decrees of the Council of Trent, reformed clergy education, and cared for plague victims. He is a model of pastoral zeal, devotion to the sacraments, and Church renewal.

Saint Bertilla of Italy, a 7th-century Benedictine nun, was known for her piety and leadership in monastic life. She helped found and oversee convents, promoting prayer, work, and charity among her sisters. Her devotion to the Rule of St. Benedict left a lasting mark on religious life.

Leonard was a 6th-century Frankish nobleman who became a hermit and spiritual guide. He is known as the patron saint of prisoners, women in labor, and horses, celebrated for his intercessory prayers and miracles of liberation and healing.

Willibrord, born in England in 658, was a missionary and bishop who evangelized the Frisians in the Netherlands and northern Germany. He founded churches and monasteries, becoming the first Archbishop of Utrecht. His missionary zeal helped spread Christianity northward in Europe.

Saint Dieudonné was a French martyr who, along with companions, witnessed to the Christian faith at the cost of his life during the early centuries of the Church. Their steadfastness under persecution inspires faithfulness to Christ.

Theodore of Tarsus was an Archbishop of Canterbury born in 602 in Cilicia. He played a major role in harmonizing the English church, founding schools, and promoting learning. His wisdom and leadership helped unify diverse English Christian communities.

Pope Leo the Great (400–461) was a powerful and influential leader of the Church, noted for his theological defense of Christ's two natures and his efforts to negotiate peace with barbarian tribes. His teachings shaped Church doctrine and papal authority. Canonized a Doctor of the Church.

Martin of Tours (316–397) was a Roman soldier who embraced Christianity and became a monk and later bishop known for his humility and charitable works. He famously cut his cloak in half to share with a beggar and is one of the most popular saints in Western Christianity. Canonized for his missionary zeal and care for the poor.
